Show: The Man Who Fell to Earth
Review: The series fails to recognize the key to the power of its source material: its peculiarity.

Show: The Falcon and the Winter Soldier
Review: We could've developed Bucky loads more.

Review: Although '80s-style excess clearly accounts for much of the sizzle, this exercise feels like a no-look pass that skips out of bounds.

Like the Stephen King novel it's based upon, The Outsider is an interesting, but not completely satisfying experiment... Even with Erivo and Mendelsohn as sturdy stars, ]it] hasn't quite found a way to give its plunge into the unknown the juice it needs.

Rise wants to be an inspiring drama. More accurate to describe it as a drama about wanting to be inspirational...Rise seems uninterested in its own best instincts, willing to bring up ideas but unwilling to carry them over the finish line.

Season 1 may have left audiences hot under the collar and begging for more the first time around, unfortunately its successor is more likely to leave viewers yawning, such is the state of affairs with season two.

"Peacemaker" exposes a bigger problem: in a minor role with an ensemble of zany characters, Cena's witty banter felt like a breath of fresh air. In a eight-hour episodic series with lackluster supporting players, Cena struggles to carry the load.

The show seems to be an intentional throwback, trading on Spielberg nostalgia to draw those who recognize the original, or just its family-friendly appeal, into Apple's orbit -- but it comes off more dated than deliberately retro.
What's missing here, to a depressing degree, is a sense of purpose.
If, like me, you want something deeper, you’ll find Pieces of Her’s biggest mystery will be how this tonally mismatched, structurally messy show came to be.
For a series about a pair of sharpshooters, Hawkeye frustratingly misses the mark too often. Well, at least for viewers who aren't its target audience.
It’s probably the most 2022 thing imaginable to take one adored show and reboot it in a way that feels derivative of at least a half-dozen other shows.
It is an ambitious but ultimately lacking attempt at illustrating how trauma is inherited from one generation to the next, at the expense of the protagonists’ development and season one friendship.
Unfortunately, full of filler where there should be thriller, Bodyguard just can't get the job done, literally or figuratively.

The stakes here seem to be massive; gradually, it becomes clear that an epidemic of darkness is overtaking many. But getting there, with so little in the way of character or freshness of tone, simply exhausts even an interested viewer.

Some character depth would help maintain interest for 10 episodes around a scary fog, but from the town's cops to the high school jocks, it all feels like a mediocre horror movie. That's a hard sell for 10 weeks.
I HAVE NEVER IN MY LIFE YELLED AT A SHOW LIKE THIS. I WAS ROOTING FOR YOU. WE WERE ALL ROOTING FOR YOU! HOW DARE YOU!
I never understood the appeal of The Flight Attendant, and I still don't.
The greatest crime of Loot is how much it fails its leading lady.
Not even often-stunning performances... can dig Taboo out of its messy, overwrought darkness.
It had good moments, it had bad moments, it had dull moments. I kind of wish now that there was just Season 1 standing alone as a great example of the genre...

I found myself desperately wishing for Altered Carbon to leave its world of endless lives, satellite back ups, and shapeless political revolutions behind, to focus... on the AIs discarded by humanity as yet another resource to be wasted and forgotten.
Season two's biggest shortcoming is the way it prioritized Mary-Louise at the expense of Bonnie.
The series achieves its ultimate manifestation as Saturday-afternoon animation. With Loki, Marvel, Disney, and their die-hard constituents have found ways to make the banal even more banal.
The Undoing is gratingly off-key. It invites us to sympathise with poor, rich Grace as her bubble of privilege bursts. Not right now, thanks.
Midnight Mass only really gets going in episode three. And, when it finally sets off, it doesn't seem to know where it is heading.
The bottom line is Apple has produced a series that not only fails to get under your skin, but mostly just makes you want to swat it away.
A product that delivers neither the wildly creative sense of tech's possibilities nor the ground-level excavation of his characters... Devs is a misfire for a talented creator.
There's too much talent here for Schmigadoon! to ever be a total waste, but the show is far more pandering than nurturing.
I was annoyed and rolling my eyes. I was on the edge of my seat wondering if the show would do anything truly surprising.

According to the end credits, Vigil has been made with support from the Scottish government, which makes no secret of its opposition to nuclear weapons. That may hint at an extra political edge, but doesn't make this a compelling drama.

The original run is one of TV's masterpieces, and Lynch finally returning to this project -- and unshackled by network restrictions -- was great news. In retrospect, limitations might have been welcome since this suffers from extreme excess and overkill.
Even [Justin Theroux's] absorbing performance can't make Mosquito Coast make sense.
A disappointing bleak drama that doesn't have anything new to say.
For all that money, we might have expected more. The plotting is occasionally a letdown too, bordering on infuriating.

There are peaks and valleys, but mostly there's a lot of flat, ugly middle. The victories that you spend forever building end up being as ephemeral as fireworks, sparkling briefly before quickly fading back into the endless blackness of the nighttime sky.
There's something mechanical about Lovecraft Country's horror, both real and supernatural.

The show's myopia isn't surprising. If anything, the final season proves once again that teen viewers deserved better than what 13 Reasons Why offered, and if the show is remembered in a few years, it'll be mostly for what it failed to do.
If the series wants to tackle the exploitation of labor, even in its own exaggerated way, it usually helps when the authoritarians' methods of oppression make sense—logically and emotionally...
In Anatomy of a Scandal, there is the matter of what constitutes consent and what is rape. But the muddled storytelling leaves the victim behind.
The empty characterization isn't egregious, but it seems like an apparatus that's been built around some hidden central engine the show doesn't want to reveal. Why are these people like this?
It's a season that betrays its own legacy and destroys the absolute brilliance of the first season.
You can violate the laws of the universe you created, using a raft of new characters in whom we have no investment, or you can drag nine episodes' worth of doing so over 22 hours of TV. Not both.
Optimism isn't a bad thing to have on TV shows, but when that's the only thing you've got going for you, living up to "amazing" seems like a reach.
While it celebrates women who break the mold, the show itself is deeply — and dispiritingly — conventional.
Lots of people have bad childhoods and boring spouses yet never end up becoming sexual predators. Where's the limited series about those people?
The final episodes were just awful. Everything that kept me from really bonding with the series about a family breaking bad was on display in those last hours.
There's only one vaguely interesting formula tweak here and it's Mancini's decision to make his protagonist queer and then to handle it with a refreshingly casual sensitivity.
Now I've had it with people who insist on making themselves miserable, as if it were an art.

While The Undoing strings together just enough surprises to keep viewers interested episode-to-episode, its writing and direction are both muddled, making for an occasionally unpleasant viewing experience.
"Hawkeye" is too beholden to the larger MCU as a guiding narrative force and generic house style of filming to truly find its own voice...
Elena is thinly drawn as an obviously villainous "white savior" and Witherspoon is repeating her performance from Big Little Lies with less nuance and shading.
The Beatles: Get Back documentary proves once again that Peter Jackson's meticulous approach to filmmaking is impressive but excessive.
The fifth season of Black Mirror isn't necessary bad -- each episode has a glimmer of something exciting -- but unfortunately that didn't quite go far enough.

The back half of this miniseries is so bogged down by inconsistent pacing, drawn-out scenes, muddled plotting, and a frustratingly anticlimactic ending that all the good Lisey's Story delivers before that collapse ends up overshadowed.
It’s all pretty perfunctory and over-reliant on one single, repetitive plot point that ends up not being scary, sinister, or engaging enough to compel you to see what comes next.
Stripping this story of pretty much every shred of dramatic weight and emotional engagement is no easy task, but CBS has accomplished it

As much as The Wheel of Time left me indifferent, I very much warmed to the universe of the Aes Sedais. Your introduction to them is Moiraine, and it's difficult not to be intrigued by her order. She's the type of woman who doesn't hear "no" often.

For a show with a wild central premise and a goofily brazen title, nothing here rises to the level of wildness that the show is teasing, nor is there the sort of grounding that could work as an alternative.
This potentially provocative, supernatural sci-fi series is unfocused and uneven.
Despite some evocative (and provocative) visuals and appropriate dramatic tension, it fails to truly excite.

It's almost hard to believe that stars Nicole Kidman and Hugh Grant, series writer David E. Kelley and series director Susanne Bier could come up with a show so limp, so generic, so dispiritingly bad as this six-hour drama.
This drawn-out, plodding miniseries stretches every one of its meager strengths beyond its breaking point.
"Entourage" heads into its final eight episodes starting Sunday night and to be honest, it's time.
There's a reason the phrase "You can't go home again" amounts to a cliché. You really can't. Especially when home is a prison.
"Mayor of Kingstown" appears tailor-made to be forever confused with 100 other shows like it, shackled and forgotten in its allegiance to an outdated template.
House of Cards never quite maintains momentum, again; the first five episodes sent to critics are sometimes promising, sometimes plodding.
Between the series’s somewhat nondescript visual style and its overwhelming exposition, Halo is bogged down by world-building and almost hampered by its source material.

Those who've been just as mystified, expecting a third season to answer the many questions it's raised, or at least a deeper dive following the supernatural events of the Season One cliffhanger, will be terribly disappointed.
The Affair Season 5 Episode 1 was a colossal waste of time.

The season feels incomplete, an insufficient and far too economical kiss off for such an intricately constructed show. It's sad to see a world built with the breadth of the universe have no room to breathe.
With only 52 minutes of running time, The Cellar feels like a TV movie condensed to the length of a TV episode. Its characters are painted in wide brush strokes.
This is the very definition of “treading water TV”, despite its big-budget fanciness, Stranger Things is really no different from any generic network procedural.

Invasion proceeds so incrementally across such a wide range of characters and their responses to extraterrestrial terrorism that you might well lose your way from week to week. Never mind your interest.
Morris' book meticulously chronicled a wilderness of errors. All Smerling's documentary does is get lost in a wilderness of voices.
This is the very definition of “treading water TV”, despite its big-budget fanciness, Stranger Things is really no different from any generic network procedural.
Feels like something ABC might have aired in 1997.
The Beatles: Get Back only truly comes to life when the eponymous band performs, and it happens far less than you might want over the course of 8 hours.
Thinking ruins it in a very specific ways. Kick the mental tires too much on this genre romance, and the whole thing slides right into Skeeveyville.
Unfortunately, the resulting product is frequently too on-the-nose. If there’s any reason to watch, it’s for the performance of actor Matthew Goode as legendary Paramount executive Robert Evans.

Show: Once Upon a Time in Wonderland
Review: Unless Alice and her rabbit pal have more tricks up their sleeve than Snow White and the gang could muster, ABC's visit to Wonderland might once again leave the network less in need of a looking glass than a rear-view mirror.
The fifth season of Black Mirror isn't necessary bad -- each episode has a glimmer of something exciting -- but unfortunately that didn't quite go far enough.
The series works best when it focuses on intimate, human moments rather than on broad social critiques.
Maybe the show will get better; I hope it does. But with so many shows on so many different platforms right now, it seems like Amazing Stories blew its one chance to make a good first impression.

Show: Once Upon a Time in Wonderland
Review: With the mothership's leads on a similar quest for a missing boy, Wonderland seems like an exercise in magical redundancy. This looking glass is cracked.
Although its fantastic to have Mike Myers back in action, the series is underwhelming in elaborating its premise and comedy. [Full review in Spanish]
Mainly what held my interest in The Shrink Next Door was the myriad reasons it doesn't quite work.
Players fell short of the mark for me.
It's curiously bland, devoid of most of the scares that King is known for, and telling a straightforward story in a faithful but lifeless manner.
Events, characters and half-formed ideas are thrown at the screen then abandoned in favour of fresh mysteries, the show infinitely rolling out a carpet of kookiness.
The end result is a season that is overstuffed and yet drags, as though the boys sucked all the energy out of the first season, as they do.
It's just never compelling, never engrossing and, worst of all, not thought-provoking to the degree it needs to be given its subject matter and acclaimed, if dated, source material.
Stripping this story of pretty much every shred of dramatic weight and emotional engagement is no easy task, but CBS has accomplished it
On paper, the idea of building a new democracy from the ruins of war while government contractors run amok is just as strong as the original premise of Jericho. But the execution remains mediocre.
Now I've had it with people who insist on making themselves miserable, as if it were an art.

While lots of action films require the audience to suspend disbelief at times, Treadstone requires them to saw the tops of their own heads off and remove the gooey blob inside. It's the only way you'll survive the writing.
There’s a lot of blurriness of intention around the storytelling in The Thing About Pam and an ultimately complacent belief that Renée Zellweger slurping on soda is enough to count as Emmy bait.
Night Sky begins as a beautiful coming-of-old-age story, but it splinters into an overstuffed sci-fi thriller.
House of Cards never quite maintains momentum, again; the first five episodes sent to critics are sometimes promising, sometimes plodding.
A dour, flavorless combination of familiar crime-drama elements, led by Renner at his most glum.
A watchable if often underwhelming true crime docudrama that wants to both be weird and play it safe, ending up in a strange middle ground between the two.

It is a show that takes itself so seriously that, when former child actor Thomas Brodie-Sangster turns up dressed like an escapee from the Wild West, you don't know whether it's meant to be funny or not
There are jokes about what it means to be an everyday woman, but they're sprinkled in among jokes about what it must be like to be Amy Schumer, and it messes with the voice of the show.

One of the major issues of Peele's debut season was the runtime for episodes. This season is no exception, and of the three episodes screened, only one truly earns the extra half-hour - and even then, it could easily be chiseled down.
I'm not sure if they got the physics exactly right, but The Big Bang Theory somehow ended not with a breakup but an "I love you."
There's too much talent here for Schmigadoon! to ever be a total waste, but the show is far more pandering than nurturing.
You could forgive all this if these episodes were funny, if they contained even a trace of the spark that made its first run so incredible. But they aren't. They're flat and lifeless and pointless.
The feel-good moments at the end don't make up for six seasons of stringing viewers along without ever providing any real answers or any real closure.
Ten episodes in, you don’t come away feeling you know the stories of these women any better, any deeper, than you already did.

I found myself desperately wishing for Altered Carbon to leave its world of endless lives, satellite back ups, and shapeless political revolutions behind, to focus... on the AIs discarded by humanity as yet another resource to be wasted and forgotten.
The empty characterization isn't egregious, but it seems like an apparatus that's been built around some hidden central engine the show doesn't want to reveal. Why are these people like this?
There's too much talent here for Schmigadoon! to ever be a total waste, but the show is far more pandering than nurturing.

You've got to appreciate the moxie of a high-profile streaming series where a character blurts, "Another streaming service? It should be illegal." That's The Morning Show's second season in a nutshell: having its cake while choking on it.
Hawkeye feels like it will end up being a quick wiki article scan to get caught up on where everything stands instead of its own standalone story.

To me, it felt like an hourlong f--- you from a guy who has seen fan devotion for The Sopranos transform him from a little-known but well respected TV producer into one of the most legendary TV auteurs in history.
A tedious, tiresome mess that almost put me to sleep.
This spy thriller hitches its wagon to an insufferable performance.
It's called Joe vs. Carole, but it should have been called Dumb vs Dumber.

In the moments when Claire is allowed not just the camera but the story, "House of Cards" is a ride; when the past is relitigated and the specter of Frank rears up once more, it feels like that worst thing a binge-able drama can be: a trudge.
It's delivered in an oddly-paced season that fights against an intuitive structure as much as these students try to beat back chomps from throngs of kids in uniforms.
It's just an unlikely space opera, overlong, clunkily put together and not the slightest bit amusing.

There's some symmetry in the fact that after eight years, four Emmys, three regional managers, and an untold number of parties in the conference room, The Office's farewell feels more like an afterthought than an event.
Out of all the thriller fare that Kelley has adapted for the small screen to date, the whole of Anatomy of a Scandal is disappointingly much less compelling than the sum of its parts.
In practice, Joe vs. Carole feels like a brutally over-extended Saturday Night Live sketch, leaning heavily on the jokes we know and expect while clumsily trying to tease out some deeper meaning.

The issue isn't that The Undoing tries to channel Big Little Lies, but that it does so unsuccessfully. Even in its failures, however, The Undoing made me dream of a world where TV could crack the code...
I honestly can't tell whether or not Mulder's dialogue is supposed to sound ridiculous (in the second episode he utters this baffling phrase: "Scully, you looked so adorbs").
With listless pacing and no characters to care about... Taboo, you win. You're the best at being the worst.

It's much better paced and way easier to watch. But coming back from what was a truly lack-luster first season... was going to take a complete overhaul of the series and it's hard to say if that was ever going to be possible.
Stranger Things is still Stranger Things. It just now comes with astoundingly thick levels of padding.
...the series is driven by a muddle-headed and confused notion about what's wrong with the U.S...
In its attempt to build a bigger world, the series falls prey to more fantasy tropes than it masters.
Although the series could have continued - maybe by introducing zombies or mummies - True Blood had nowhere to go but in circles. It was time to put a stake in it.
For the most part, we're left with an unsexy portrait of decadence, a thriller without thrills, a prescription that's less soma than Sominex.
So many great actors, so little for most of them to do. Good acting can get you through times of confused and misguided writing, but can only take a show so far.
Considering just how beloved Y: The Last Man is and its long development period, it's disappointing that the show's opening episodes aren't better.

Boone and Cavell make a series of choices that not only diminish the awesome terror of the first part of King's novel, but the characters themselves, their journeys, and any reason we should care about them.
A Wilderness of Error is a fascinating and informative look at a notorious piece of American history, but it struggles to defend its own relevance.
The first episode in the new season lasts eight hours and 24 minutes. No, not really. It does feel interminable, though.
The goal shouldn’t be about being everything to everyone, and while “Halo” treats the source material with respect, it does so with a tentativeness, as if it is afraid to miss a key element.

This meaty showcase for Jared Leto and Anne Hathaway is wrapped in a somewhat malnourished limited series, with the misfortune of coming at the tail end of several better productions about high-stakes startups whose founders flew too close to the sun.
This show should have been a home run. In my opinion the missed opportunity lies in three areas: the story, the pacing and the direction.
It does eventually bed in somewhat, but not as much as it should.

Show: The Man Who Fell to Earth
Review: The split timeline is a plague on TV, and its latest victim is Showtime’s The Man Who Fell to Earth.
The final episodes were just awful. Everything that kept me from really bonding with the series about a family breaking bad was on display in those last hours.
To call The Staircase a docu-series is a gross exaggeration. It is filmed entirely from the perspective of Peterson's team, an overwrought exploration of a self-involved family.
Bel-Air is a glossy, expensive-looking soap that, like Fox’s Our Kind of People, puts the spotlight on uber-wealthy Black families. But “fresh?” Not so much.
For a series set in the infinite vastness of a multiverse, What If...? is dreaming awfully small.
At some point, Fringe kind of fell in love with change for its own sake, and it wandered away for long periods from what powered its finest moments - the complex bonds among Olivia, Peter and Walter.

This new version has its inspired moments, like the way Billy Joel's "The Stranger" somehow turns out to be the perfect theme song for Flagg, but the structure keeps sucking the life out of things, from major characters to more minor ones.

Show: The Last Days of Ptolemy Grey
Review: What audiences get is a family melodrama where mental illness is addressed on the way to another destination. There’s no doubting the sincerity of those involved, but ultimately this glossy slice of streaming content lacks teeth in its latter stages...

A decent production budget and starry cast led by Tom Hiddleston and Claire Danes are squandered on a dreary, convoluted, portentous drama with all the appeal of a fog blanket over a giant rotting fish which someone briefly mistook for a dead dragon.
Yet while Limitless is competently executed, what it lacks, finally, is any spark of inspiration. And alas, there's no pill for that.
The eight-episode season easily could’ve been boiled down into two TikToks...
Even a show that approaches its episodic run like an extra-long movie owes the audience a bit more momentum than this, especially when those installments roll out weekly.
A story that lacks strength... torn between what it wants to tell and how. [Full review in Spanish]

The only times The Mist manages to escape the obvious is in the story of a possible teen sexual assault, which feels slightly more rooted in character and reality but takes a backseat to the show's title malevolent force.
It's too much buildup for too little payoff. By the time the series is ready to launch, we're already charting a course for somewhere else.
While beautiful to look at, the show struggles to say something compelling as it's more interested in amplifying the melodrama instead of delving deep into its more interesting subjects.

In trying to make the show about gossip and the media, Inventing Anna actually misses whatever it is that Anna herself was up to and rather focused on what she thought she was doing. Instead of adding complexity, it just comes off as muddled.
While the diminishing returns of the shows narrative are a disappointment, the moral implications of its wide-ranging smorgasbord of social commentary are bewildering, if not outright alarming.
This show is hellbent on driving me mad thanks to one of its biggest stumbling blocks: the absence of any sort of logic to this universe.

Garland's vision is in the forefront here, and the result is a limited series with a frosty emotional tone, and a story heavy on cutting-edge techno-speak, but skimpy when it comes to characterization.
No programme is more infuriatingly chuffed with itself.
Not even often-stunning performances... can dig Taboo out of its messy, overwrought darkness.
Every bit of this story is as weird as hell. The trouble is that, on screen, weirdness itself doesn't really give you very far to go.
A thin story spread over a lot of hours, but Ali is excellent and so is his support.
This is the most apocalyptic-y apocalypse ever, but it carries no real weight. Then when you find out what has to be done to save the universe, it just feels very underwhelming. Samurais, really?
The end product is comedically wan, the double-takes broad and all the Olsen/Bettany/Hahn charm squeezed into tiny dabs of screen time
In the best and worst exploitation tradition, "Striking Vipers" warns you not to treat others as a game. Then it goes ahead and does exactly that.
Little fires will quickly merge into an overwhelming flame, and even though this is the first scene of the series, Hulu's adaptation goes right ahead and burns itself out.
The feel-good moments at the end don't make up for six seasons of stringing viewers along without ever providing any real answers or any real closure.
Invasion is a ten-hour season devoid of nearly all humor, where characters across the globe continually bumble around in their own misery, resentful that aliens keep interrupting their tragic lives.
Still fun on its own terms, the encore takes an unexpected little gem and transforms it into Murder, She (and She and She and She) Wrote.
On both the teen and super aspects, this series misses the mark.

The frustrating thing about Halo is that it tries to serve two masters -- diehard Halo fans and newbies who are used to the normal rhythms of sci-fi streaming series -- and doesn’t quite please either.
It's all extremely rote, like an expanded version of the mid-budget Nineties movie that would have starred Kidman and Grant at their respective heights of celebrity.
This Seventies flashback tries to hit a lot of marks at once... The only way it genuinely works, however, is as a parody of prestige TV.
These great clunking scenes are not only dull and unnecessary, they also draw unwanted attention to Boardwalk's greatest weakness. Empathy can't be retconned. It has to be earned.

Season 2 timidly skimmed the surface of such representation when I needed it to leap into sumptuous storytelling. I couldn’t escape into it while I was also trying to navigate its unsatisfying approach to inclusivity.
This update brings the star power of Jessica Chastain and Oscar Isaac, but can't match the emotional intensity of the original.

There are peaks and valleys, but mostly there's a lot of flat, ugly middle. The victories that you spend forever building end up being as ephemeral as fireworks, sparkling briefly before quickly fading back into the endless blackness of the nighttime sky.
To call The Staircase a docu-series is a gross exaggeration. It is filmed entirely from the perspective of Peterson's team, an overwrought exploration of a self-involved family.
Hulu trotted out Little Fires Everywhere, an eight-part limited series that attempts to capture the sprawling nature of the source material, but ultimately fails.
After that first hour, you may be holding back tears. But after seven more, your eyes have glazed over, and even these luminous stars can’t bring you back to Earth.
... Rise feels like a rehash, a collection of stories we've already seen, presented with a slightly darker palette.

Inventing Anna transforms a juicy real-life drama about a con artist among the influencer crowd into a fairly inert limited series, in part by giving almost equal weight to the reporter who broke the story.
Lisey's Story is, on all fronts, too much. Too long, too over-produced, too many talents, too overwrought, too much going on.

Morena Baccarin and Ryan Michelle Bathe, longtime supporting players getting starring roles in a large-scale series for the first time, do not feel irreplaceable, and the show's clunky, obvious writing doesn't give them much to work with.
You end up wondering whether they are true soulmates, or just trauma-bonded beyond redemption. Christ, you think, move on, but, alas, they won't.
A bunch of supposed adults complaining about having to take a dump in a latrine.
The tension all goes slack, formerly compelling characters end up being waved at each other like wooden dolls, and yet another prestige drama leaves the audience wondering why they bothered.
Raised by Wolves wafts into emotional and narrative oblivion.

Lovecraft Country feels like a missed opportunity to repurpose the racist fear at the heart of Lovecraft's work to articulate the specific dread, isolation, and social death felt by Black people in all corners of the world.

A show like this one is so busy saying something about the justice system and the prison-industrial complex that it rarely has a moment to consider that one of the injustices here is that a person was killed.
It is a bleak drama series that doesn't seem to bring anything new to the table
If Stephen King could go back in time, maybe he'd decide to stop selling his books to television.

The Wheel Of Time is definitely a talky mess of a show, at least to start. It throws a lot of characters at us, but somehow all the time taken to establish them doesn't give us any more idea about them than when the episode started.

It succumbed to the bane of American TV -- the endless more-more-more of anything good or popular, the twisting of characters into pretzels to simply keep them in motion, the cheap substitutes after lead actors depart.
After a few chapters, Bodyguard does something that is as bold as it is absurd, changing all the pieces of the game, but losing all cohesion. [Full review in Spanish]
If the iconic image of "Sex and the City" is its central quartet striding down a Manhattan sidewalk, this is a series on its back heels: defensive, reactive, terrified to offend.
The true scandal is how lazy it all feels.
I got to wondering: didn't we reach a climax in our relationship with Carrie, Samantha, Charlotte and Miranda sooner than any of us would dare to admit?
There are too many characters, too many high-stakes plotlines, and not enough explanation for how it all connects.
It all feels very much as if Line Of Duty is running out of energy and impetus. Six seasons is one too many.
A lot of basic and mundane things don't add up for me.
Why are we coming back to all these people again?
The light fun of it is eaten away by the cynicism from within the project, that what purports to be about infinite possibilities is blatantly more about repurposing.
Remembering Peter Weir's 1986 film, a descent-into-madness tragedy set entirely on the titular coast of Honduras, could be more of a hindrance to enjoying this new take.

The dull courtroom sequences occasionally slip into stagey reconstructions of what happened between defendant and accused. At no point does Kelley’s series pause to consider what it is it’s trying to say about, um, well, anything.
This finale seems to completely sour the show's legacy - something that is not more important than ever.

It's nevertheless a bit of a letdown when you realize halfway through the dense first episode that one of the MCU's ostensibly most unpredictable lead characters has somehow landed in the most predictable of setups.
The first episode in the new season lasts eight hours and 24 minutes. No, not really. It does feel interminable, though.

While the new kids at McKinley get a few quirky gags, they feel half-hearted, as if only real remaining mission is to follow our old friends to the finish line. That's fine. But we could have done it two seasons ago and not missed much.
The writers' decision to go full cheeseball ending shouldn't have been surprising, after the show spent its last year turning into a frustrating shadow of itself.
Unfortunately for the show, even without the controversies putting a cloud over proceedings, the simple fact of the matter is that this season just isn't that good.
"A Very English Scandal" plays too much with tragedy.
Looking back, the real Scandal was that anyone kept watching.
The show feels like more Star Wars: Clone Wars, and yet never reaches the heights that it's sister series did, and ultimately doesn't find it's own voice as a result.

Preacher Season 4 starts strong, but it can't escape the snare of mediocrity, no matter how much craziness it throws our way. And while the show is rarely subjectively bad, it continues to have issues with tone and characterizations.
Headaches will be induced just in trying to unravel the plot mess Bon Temps finds itself in. At least this will be the last headache.
There is potential in here, though, especially through the committed performances from the cast. But right now The Mysterious Benedict Society needs more mysteries and fewer answers.
After a certain point, you stop questioning things and instead enter a fugue state. Is time passing, or are you just stuck in some horrendous ten-minute long Groundhog Day?
A bunch of supposed adults complaining about having to take a dump in a latrine.

Flashes of brilliance offer a glimpse of the more introspective, imaginative show we were promised, and the finale has the opportunity to deliver. As it stands, though, Marvel Studios' latest Disney+ outing is also its most disappointing.
I don't think anyone can be happy that this season focused, in the end, on Jon Snow, the least complicated main character on an ensemble full of brutal instincts and grasping ambition.
The newest MCU series on Disney+ has some interesting ideas and cool authentically Egyptian flavor, but takes its own little time to get rolling.
The Pentaverate struggles under the weight of its main talent.

Somehow... the series keeps from being overwhelmed by all the changes, either to its characters or the world around them, and winds up in delivering an emotionally satisfying end to one of Hulu's most charming and enjoyable series.
The willing suspension of disbelief has to be earned, and from where I'm standing, The OA doesn't earn it.

If the series accomplishes nothing else, it’s guaranteed to teach a few audience members stories they didn’t know before. It’s just too bad that in its messiness, Gaslit stops somewhere short of doing them justice.

Overall the first four episodes made available for review plod along... But then, just as I'm about to write off this final season, something happens at the end of the fourth episode that pulls me right back in. Just like Carrie, I can't seem to let go.
The series might all be called Amazing Stories, But Not So Amazing That Heart Patients Can't Watch It.

Show: Web of Make Believe: Death, Lies & the Internet
Review: While all of the subjects covered in the six episodes sound very interesting a lot of the oomph is taken out of them due to the repetitive and drawn out nature of each.
We know who these people are. They're clichés -- not unpleasant but wholly unsurprising.

Colman Domingo was as good as always, but all the exposition dumps and plot holes really dragged the [premiere] down, blunting what could have -- in more adept hands -- been a strong opener for Season Seven.
In declining to conjecture what WeWork’s nosedive meant for the rest of us, it’s got even less of a purpose than a co-working space during a pandemic.
'Shadow and Bone' is trying to show way too much in too little time, leaving its best intentions emotionally stunted and inert.
Big Shot, while perfectly amiable in most respects, often fails to sweat the details in the way that a tough coach would demand.
Euphoria is unrelentingly explicit this time around, as if it took one look at its former self and thought: no, not shocking enough, try this.
With or without Kevin Spacey, it's possible that House of Cards had simply run its course. It's just a shame that it couldn't make one final sprint toward the finish line.
Almost completely misses.
More exhausting than thrilling, Netflix's latest period fantasy adventure, "Shadow and Bone," will have a tough time breaking out of the fan base already built by the books.
While Stiles is missed in the last batch of episodes, this fun MTV show finds a nice way to say goodbye.
Gone are the days when HBO would produce only outright classics targeted at discerning audiences - in the streaming age, a wider clientele must be catered to.

There are interesting ideas and some refreshing roles here, languorously trailed among the endless vistas. But these ideas flare and subside in the slow sprawl of the show, without the assurance of a guiding hand.

With only eight episodes in the series, it’s time to stop idling and hit the gas pedal. And new characters and errant plot threads only hinder what should be the driving force of the series, namely the Eve and Villanelle relationship.
As with some of Apple's other high budget series, the desire to look massive overtakes a lean narrative... This is probably the priciest slow burner show ever made.

All over the map... Rod Serling had overworked himself into a state of total burnout from which he would never fully recover.
The reality is that Prison Break in 2017 is basically a collection of ideas that Homeland passed on, if you can imagine that.
You wouldn't be alone in feeling that this season of Agent Carter lacked a certain urgency...that's really the rub, that Season 2 never seemed like it had enough to say on Peggy's journey...
There is too much time to fill, too many episodes to stretch a fairly thin plot across, and too many goddamn strangers to stay interested in any one of them.

Though it's based on the Wondery podcast that first broke the tawdry tiger tale in 2019, Joe vs. Carole simply doesn't contain enough fresh insight to justify its existence today  despite game performances by the stars.

Show: Once Upon a Time in Wonderland
Review: Why borrow a classic if you're not going to do anything with it?

The Endgame is by turns boring and by other turns generic and nonsensical. Its story isn’t compelling enough to follow beyond the first episode, and we’re figuring that the interplay between its stars isn’t enough to keep people watching.

Spending five-plus hours watching a very average man inch toward slightly greater self-awareness doesn't make for the most powerful TV experience.

In trying to make the show about gossip and the media, Inventing Anna actually misses whatever it is that Anna herself was up to and rather focused on what she thought she was doing. Instead of adding complexity, it just comes off as muddled.
It should be weird and captivating! Instead, The Baby meanders...
Bafflingly, it's a workplace comedy. Note to Disney: children don't go to work.
Rven though the circumstances are new... it still felt like déjà vu. We have had this vibe, this dynamic before - many times.

Atill struggling with the same generic Marvel-on-Netflix issue: a master plot that just isn't dense enough to stretch over the episode order, leading to stop-and-start pacing, repetitive conversations and secondary characters that overstay their welcome.

More and more, the show seems to be saying, Joe's struggles are just a slightly amped-up version of the viewer's own. He's "You." But there's too much grotesque violence in the show's past for us to relate to him, or to take the show on its own terms.

As rendered in this iteration of King's epic, that mix of realism and fantasy results in a disjointed, tonally inconsistent work that manages to both over-condense aspects of the original saga and overstay its welcome.
If you don't stand for something, you end up looking like a Walking Dead spin-off that never made it to the air.
I swear to God, I don't think I could come up with a worse ending.
A disappointing bleak drama that doesn't have anything new to say.
A lot of people do good work on “Open Range.” If only it provided a little more to hold onto.
With its many subplots, some more compelling than others, it's an uneven series that's not so much a must-watch as a can-watch.
By the time the last three episodes roll around, House of Cards' final season has abruptly buried itself in a whole host of weird, borderline anti-feminist tropes.
Midnight Mass only really gets going in episode three. And, when it finally sets off, it doesn't seem to know where it is heading.

With only eight episodes in the series, it’s time to stop idling and hit the gas pedal. And new characters and errant plot threads only hinder what should be the driving force of the series, namely the Eve and Villanelle relationship.
For fans of westerns, 1883 certainly looks like the real deal, coming from Yellowstone creator Taylor Sheridan and featuring Sam Elliott as a gnarled cowboy. The execution, however, feels stale.
No programme is more infuriatingly chuffed with itself.

Limitless comes off as rote, slick and bloodless.The show is based on the film of the same name and expect occasional Bradley Cooper drop-ins, but unless Limitless lives up to its name and starts achieving far more of its potential, I'll pass.

It's clear that Guilty Party has set out to spin a narrative about a complicated woman working a complicated case. But at this point in the story, the whole thing seems on the verge of buckling under one complication too many.
HBO hired Julian Fellowes to make a Downton Abbey out of 1880s NYC. But all the fussy costumes and jewelry in the world can’t bring The Gilded Age’s story of old vs. new money to life.
Got some good laughs out of the first three episodes, but I grew weary.

It became... nothing more than a Hayley Atwell vehicle that let everything else from production value to narrative importance fall to the wayside if it meant the show's lead actress getting in just one extra spunky line of dialogue.
The goal shouldn’t be about being everything to everyone, and while “Halo” treats the source material with respect, it does so with a tentativeness, as if it is afraid to miss a key element.
[Tom] acts like a complex hero in this post-"Sopranos" era, but the aimless writing and the arty editing leave him flat.

The Endgame is the sort of show that believes it can compete with an international hit like Money Heist by staging seven simultaneous bank takeovers, while giving us precious little reason to care what happens in any of them.
If the series wants to tackle the exploitation of labor, even in its own exaggerated way, it usually helps when the authoritarians' methods of oppression make sense—logically and emotionally...
The lack of proper development for its teen girls is the most troubling aspect of "Big Shot," all things considered, the element that feels the most performative.
Despite some admirable efforts by its committed cast, this version of The Lincoln Lawyer never makes a compelling case for its lengthy and laborious existence.

For the first 3 1/2 episodes, the filmmakers and contributing scholars do a reasonably good job of appearing unbiased...Where they drop the ball in a major way is in the last 15 minutes when their unabashed, vainglorious stripes are revealed.

This hodgepodge of underdeveloped themes is augmented by run-of-the-mill action sequences that not only lack invention but also emotional thrust. Mohamed Diab’s first foray into Hollywood is a giant folly with a lot of promise and too little reward.
Shadow and Bone could use some intimacy! Its conflicts as currently written are way too big and too abstract; its characters are too generic and undefined.
There are shows that flow cohesively and others that feel like several scenes meshed together, and 'Shadow and Bone' has many lost in the mesh.
Netflix's new horror show Archive 81 offers promising scares and intrigue across the board, but in its execution, it forgets the most important thing: the characters.
It's a deeply terrifying story of manipulation and abuse that plays like a comedy, sometimes when it doesn't mean to, but isn't all that funny when it's trying to be.
Lost crashed, and crashed hard... This season wasn't a long con. It was a weak trick.
'The Pentaverate' is unbelievably bad.

Show: Winning Time: The Rise of the Lakers Dynasty
Review: Winning Time is guaranteed to turn the stomachs of not only Boston Celtics fans, but anyone hoping for more than an egregiously cartoonish and ham-fisted hagiography executed with all the subtlety of a no-look pass.

The contemporary anxiety 24 hopes to exploit this time around is of drones and of the increasingly dehumanized nature of warfare, but it has become a sort of dehumanized show, populated by barely human characters.
Of course the characters don't have free will. That would require imagination, something Devs can only simulate.
The show creates its own problems in telling this story, especially as it can't seem to handle the scope.
It's probably a Marmite drama, but in its preoccupation with being clever-clever and abstruse, it has made its characters too insipid and humourless to give a monkey's about.
This weird mix of space and steampunk will confuse viewers rather than confound them.
Despite the show's few thrills, its structure only reveals an unsteady grasp of the story at its center.
"A Wilderness of Error" offers a not-so-illuminating message that it's sometimes difficult to get at the truth that's not worth the five hours it takes to hear it.
Bodyguard adds to a long and damaging media trend of depicting brown people as terrorists.
Despite able performers and potent themes, the show is so addicted to chaos that it squanders its chance to say anything substantive.

While the strong ensemble cast made for a promising set-up, the series was besmirched by an increasingly infuriating script and a trite ending that had this viewer hurling decaying vegetables at the screen.
The script's plotholes... [starts] so many stories that, in the dent, it doesn't end up providing the screen time that each one deserves. [Full review in Spanish]
House of Cards never quite maintains momentum, again; the first five episodes sent to critics are sometimes promising, sometimes plodding.
It would, at this point, take a truly inspired interpretation to make a Time Traveler’s Wife series work. Sadly, this ain’t it.
And Just Like That... A New Chapter of Sex and the City is a clumsy, cringe-inducing revival that fails to recapture the magic of the original.

Joe vs. Carole is competently made and entertaining enough but having already sat through the first season of Netflix’s bloated Tiger King, Joe vs. Carole can’t help but feel like a rerun of something I already saw.
The show is filled with unnecessary rapes, voyeuristic violence against women, and frivolous female nudity.
Once fizzy and stuffed with A-list cameos, Entourage ends on a flat note and with a recurring role for Andrew Dice Clay.

Show: Once Upon a Time in Wonderland
Review: As in Once, the computer-generated landscapes and creatures don't quite work - they look unworldly, but in a cheesy way.
Only near the very end does "The First" strap in for another go, after viewers have endured far too much narrative flourish.
If you're over ten years old, you've seen everything here before.
There are jokes about what it means to be an everyday woman, but they're sprinkled in among jokes about what it must be like to be Amy Schumer, and it messes with the voice of the show.
An Apple TV+ comedy series with one murder, plenty of suspects and minimal intrigue -- the sort of show that's modestly entertaining but doesn't bring enough to the party.
Treating this saga mostly as a shocking play-by-play with a reptilian boogeyman at the center feels a little cheap.

There’s not enough substance or character development here to hold our attention beyond the time it takes to click “NEXT.”
The Apple TV+ limited series lands in the shallow end of the King cinematic pool, with a convoluted story that mostly squanders its big-name cast.

No one would figure going back in time to spare the life of JFK would be easy or quick. But does it have to drag on so long and be this tiresome to watch?

The six-part series isn't as rich as Simon's past work, in large part because it's built almost entirely out of rage. That's understandable -- but exhausting.
True Detective Season 3 is a little more workmanlike and less baroque, perhaps too eager to prove that it can tell a legible story again.

Invincible has the potential to become a better show, but only if the makers move beyond this adolescent mockery of a superhero series and into a zone of mature storytelling. The ingredients are already there. The mixing needs to be better.

The Last Man on Earth remains very much on the bubble.

Ultimately, it’s got enough amusing moments and talented performers to offer some comedic escapism once a week, but anyone looking for another “Shadows” or “Flight of the Conchords,” should sail to other waters.

It's interesting to think and write about-a show that's about control, order, chaos, and the unknowable notions of free will, determinism, and choice-but mildly entertaining, at best, as a whole.

None of these characters speak like human beings.

Technophobic and misogynistic... you're better than this, Twilight Zone.

What we're left with is a disjointed poorer show. One that's trying to go in various directions, but doesn't always have the room for it, despite the crazy runtimes. I'm afraid Stranger Things 4 has gotten too big for its own good.

More of an exercise in frustration than anything else.
Mr. Corman is billed as a "comedy," somehow, but it's missing the laughs. It seems to be going for cringe comedy, but we just end up cringing. I felt more sad watching it than anything.
Awkward and flat, never matching the promise of its premise.

Toni Collette is a divine being sent from Heaven with whom we are all fortunate to share time on the same planet. Even Collette, however, cannot redeem what is one of television history’s most worthless characters in Netflix’s Pieces of Her.

You finish each episode with a nasty taste in your mouth, not helped by the fact that so many of the characters are so ghastly you wish they’d all self-explode and put us out of our misery.
I'm as game as the next fan for a new House. This just isn't there yet.

Explicitness abounds. However, the friction that Sex/Life chases more often turns into a rub. As it turns out, both good sex and a good life can bloom when fed full-throated fantasy. But for Sex/Life, its soapy sexuality washes away its potential potency.

When it comes to the politics of Islam, supposedly one of the main focuses of the show, Youssef shies from delving into the growing division between secular and traditional Islam. It's here where the ideology of the show grows even more muddled.

It's much better paced and way easier to watch. But coming back from what was a truly lack-luster first season... was going to take a complete overhaul of the series and it's hard to say if that was ever going to be possible.
The best part about 9 Perfect Strangers is that the Wikipedia entry states up top "not to be confused with Perfect Strangers." Oh, how I wish that this were the tale of 9 Balkis...

Well the good news is that the show is kinda-sorta ratcheting up the focus on the "what happened" story, plus it's looking more into how the country as a whole is dealing with its post-nukey self. The bad news is, I totally don't care anymore. At all.

A lot of basic and mundane things don't add up for me.
Bad wigs, limp characterization, indifferent plotting.
Godless is so swept up in the romance of the West that it shortchanges practically everything else -- character, context, story.

Show: Winning Time: The Rise of the Lakers Dynasty
Review: McKay has entered... an Aaron Sorkin-esque level of directorial obtrusiveness, where a filmmaker’s tics and indulgences keep calling attention to themselves, distracting from the narrative at hand rather than amplifying it.

Toni Collette is a divine being sent from Heaven with whom we are all fortunate to share time on the same planet. Even Collette, however, cannot redeem what is one of television history’s most worthless characters in Netflix’s Pieces of Her.
The timing is terrible. The show itself gets slightly better from there.

"Peacemaker" exposes a bigger problem: in a minor role with an ensemble of zany characters, Cena's witty banter felt like a breath of fresh air. In a eight-hour episodic series with lackluster supporting players, Cena struggles to carry the load.
A product that delivers neither the wildly creative sense of tech's possibilities nor the ground-level excavation of his characters... Devs is a misfire for a talented creator.

As is perhaps fitting, though, for a show about teenagers and their notoriously short attention spans, the writers found it hard to keep up the momentum and the quality took a dive... It has been clear the show is on its last legs.

24 is still fast-paced for the most part, although a little slow off the mark in its first hour. And the 47-year-old Sutherland remains trim and limber as an aging Jack of few words, most of them downers.
Unfortunately, the resulting product is frequently too on-the-nose. If there’s any reason to watch, it’s for the performance of actor Matthew Goode as legendary Paramount executive Robert Evans.

Shameless fails many of its other characters when it comes to their conclusions. The series even does it in such a way where it feels like the show made a deliberate choice to avoid giving a solid ending to anyone's arc.
As with most ventures like this, the total assembly is a very mixed bag of quality, dipping on the negative side of the ledger here overall.

Will those of us who've gradually fallen away return to see it out? I'm still not sure I will after seeing Thursday's Season 9 premiere
Bridgerton season 2 is a lackluster season that hopes to recapture the heights of its first but mostly falls short.
The First is never quite able to blast off.

Show: Once Upon a Time in Wonderland
Review: Unless Alice and her rabbit pal have more tricks up their sleeve than Snow White and the gang could muster, ABC's visit to Wonderland might once again leave the network less in need of a looking glass than a rear-view mirror.
The nostalgia works against the show.

It's an admirable effort, but one that simply underscores how unadaptable this material might be -- the bottom line being that if time is indeed precious, these six episodes finally feel too much like a waste of it.

Ultimately, not unlike the case explored by the detectives, accused killers, and put-upon lawyers of Interrogation, the show doesn't necessarily prove what it's actively trying to prove (crime dramas are interesting if you can choose your own fate).
Plans, schemes, endgames -- who has any use for those? The crazier Washington became, the more House of Cards lost its touch.

There’s good stuff here: Alongside Moss, Moura as the journalist aiding her, and Jamie Bell as the personification of human venality pursuing her, do fine work. But there’s simply not enough story here to make for a credible eight-episode series.

We know who these people are. They're clichés -- not unpleasant but wholly unsurprising.
Mainly what held my interest in The Shrink Next Door was the myriad reasons it doesn't quite work.

Once Upon a Time's magic is gone.
Spanning a millennium and juggling at least half-a-dozen narratives at any given moment, Foundation is suitably epic to behold, but has the emotional intensity of a lecture on particle physics.
For the most part, we're left with an unsexy portrait of decadence, a thriller without thrills, a prescription that's less soma than Sominex.

... if you have ever wished to know what you get when too many alpha males gather in a room, perhaps this is it.

The execution of the story doesn't feel balanced as an eight-episode series. It's oddly surface level at the same time never diving into the nuance or the complexities of how this could have happened.
Winding down, this series just wasn't as entertaining at the end as it was in the first few seasons
I responded to moments of Legion because I vibed with its project, but all of the aspects of that project ended up working better in other shows.

Suck all the joy, exuberance and wondrous charisma out of “The Fresh Prince” — a worthy launchpad for an actor who, in his prime, was widely considered the biggest movie star in the world — and you’re left with the gloomy and plodding “Bel-Air.”
Is Archive 81 the silliest show on telly? Probably not -- but it certainly comes close.

"Foundation" has the space for Asimov's seemingly endless plot points to breathe. Even so, it's much to take in, though creators David S. Goyer and Josh Friedman deserve kudos for making the effort at achieving the impossible.
The reality is that Prison Break in 2017 is basically a collection of ideas that Homeland passed on, if you can imagine that.
Its goofy failures create a veritable list of guidelines of how not to tell a story when otherwise trying to get across how hard it is to make a movie in Hollywood.
Hulu trotted out Little Fires Everywhere, an eight-part limited series that attempts to capture the sprawling nature of the source material, but ultimately fails.
Sadly, this show, with its cardboard characters, out-of-the-box costumes and obvious movie-set streets is all over the place. And don’t get me started on the bogus CGI architecture.
Viewers would be better off watching the Godfather saga, as its a better use of their time  and its far more entertaining than the entirety of this series.
Events, characters and half-formed ideas are thrown at the screen then abandoned in favour of fresh mysteries, the show infinitely rolling out a carpet of kookiness.

Outer Range has one of the worst momentum problems I've ever seen in a streaming show, squandering an evocative setting and some fun twists on portentous take-forever storytelling that prioritizes hints over character depth.
You can violate the laws of the universe you created, using a raft of new characters in whom we have no investment, or you can drag nine episodes' worth of doing so over 22 hours of TV. Not both.

Sometimes it seems to be a lampoon of New Age self-help fads; other times, an encomium to self-lacerating encounter-group culture; and occasionally, a creepy stalker drama. These are not the makings of a good jigsaw puzzle.
Haphazardly careens from one idea to another, throwing in themes and plot threads that never properly fit together.
I got to wondering: didn't we reach a climax in our relationship with Carrie, Samantha, Charlotte and Miranda sooner than any of us would dare to admit?
In the end, "Station Eleven" may be too attached to its rose-colored glasses.

This was most definitely not the way I wanted nor expected season five to get underway. But here's hoping somehow the show is able to catch its footing because Ogygia was a complete and utter letdown.
Far too many 2021 cultural touchstones and new characters are awkwardly parachuted into the luscious looking Michael Patrick King executive produced revival of sorts, as if to check a box.
Godless foregrounds by-the-book gunslingers and manhunts that take a promising concept and translate it into familiar, if handsomely presented, clich.
There's some good and bad with this... but at a certain point, you think "Why am I watching a miniseries about The Godfather when I could be watching The Godfather?"
It feels like a long wait at times. The first two half-hour episodes (the only ones of the 10 that were available for review) are extraordinarily slow.
The resulting eight-part miniseries is an uneven affair, at times feeling as if it's meandering through history en route to its frantic closing kick.
While some intriguing & important new elements are added, like Elliot Fletcher's trans character, the show is so concerned with big ideas it neglects all of its characters.
"Something something daddy issues" is a perilously slender thread from which to hang an entire scripted drama, and perhaps that's why the show feels so sterile.
It's baffling how a series with such a talented and star-studded cast managed to bypass prestige drama and land in the realm of soap opera.

Show: The Falcon and the Winter Soldier
Review: An incredibly frustrating story that never quite brings all of its ideas home.

Those who've been just as mystified, expecting a third season to answer the many questions it's raised, or at least a deeper dive following the supernatural events of the Season One cliffhanger, will be terribly disappointed.
Huxley's novel was revolutionary when it was published nearly 90 years ago, but the show has turned it into just another piece of consumer content.
Waco won't be the first drama to reduce a tragedy to its simplest components, but this doesn't offer much confidence that these are the right components or the only ones.
"Entourage" seems to have undergone a certain loss of identity, at least on the evidence of the first few new shows.
Sharp Objects scratches the surface of being interesting but can't overcome its dull edges.

It became... nothing more than a Hayley Atwell vehicle that let everything else from production value to narrative importance fall to the wayside if it meant the show's lead actress getting in just one extra spunky line of dialogue.
Like Delvey herself, “Inventing Anna” is all flash with little substance — offering little insight into this enigmatic figure.

The Old Man hits all the beats of a standard spy thriller and delivers some bone-crunching action, but the personal stuff falls flat. It strikes a meditative tone, without giving us much to meditate on.

If "Star Wars: Visions" does nothing else, it at least tells the story that, if only in part it's an important part, that the long time ago and the galaxy far away was maybe the Tokugawa era in feudal Japan.
A bad man getting away with a bad thing? Lawyers obfuscating the wheels of justice? It's all too familiar. And perhaps this is just 2020 talking, but it's a little exhausting, too.
Simmons and Spacek give great performances but it’s unfortunately not enough to keep Night Sky from being a dull, boring, and forgettable show.

Even the kiss that cemented Ross and Rachel couldn't disguise the show's larger anti-climax, a cop-out from the logical conclusions of the show's premise, conclusions it began to acknowledge only to ultimately deny their existence.

The show, which derived its power from the aftermath of trauma in a small community, has chosen to tell a story that's odder and bigger -- so big, in fact, that it has so far choked off what made Twin Peaks work all along.

I'd watch these characters all day under the simplicity of a spotlight and a monologue, free from the pretentious packaging. It's a shame that the show seems to get hit with a tranquilizer dart after the first couple of episodes ...
The show feels like more Star Wars: Clone Wars, and yet never reaches the heights that it's sister series did, and ultimately doesn't find it's own voice as a result.
Defending Jacob feels like a huge miss for Apple TV+.
The storytelling in this adaptation from showrunner Eric Heisserer (Bird Box. Arrival) fails to establish and maintain a momentum nearly as powerful as some of the show's magic.
Euphoria is unrelentingly explicit this time around, as if it took one look at its former self and thought: no, not shocking enough, try this.
While stylish and provocative, the series ultimately falls a little flat in its message. If a woman’s plight is to suffer, then Roar doesn’t end up giving its women a way out.
Three seasons in, the gag is starting to grow a bit old, as the satire gets weaker and more toothless and more characters vie for our attention while traveling down familiar roads.
The Time Traveler's Wife focuses so much on the time travel element, it fails to build the relationship between the lead characters, which should be the heart of the series.
Dave is still a biting satire set within the music industry that depicts the many pitfalls of making it to the main stage at Coachella. But especially this season, it's sometimes difficult to watch.
Apple's Stephen King Miniseries Starts Off Strong, Only to Quickly Fall Apart.
Despite the involvement of starry names in front of and behind the camera, intriguing fantasy elements and fascinating themes, the show never achieves the resonance it seems to be reaching for
What’s left is a show filled with so much hatred and ickiness it’s hard to believe anyone will find something to enjoy lurking inside all this muck.
As good as Anderson is throughout, her Stella suffers from a Season 3 lack of development -- we learn nothing about her in this new season that we did not know from the previous two.
In its seventh season, Pretty Little Liars illustrates the dangers of stretching a mystery as far as it can go with a splashy premiere that fails to establish real stakes for its characters.
It's often snobby and more than occasionally mean. It has a thin, subtle story, and lacks memorable set pieces.
Does this mean all of Lost counts for nothing? It's another question I can't answer.
Morris' book meticulously chronicled a wilderness of errors. All Smerling's documentary does is get lost in a wilderness of voices.

The ideas behind the premise are so good, the potential to examine existential issues about identity and humanity and how they're tied up in our physical form are so great, that it's frustrating to see how often the show takes a too-shallow approach.
These great clunking scenes are not only dull and unnecessary, they also draw unwanted attention to Boardwalk's greatest weakness. Empathy can't be retconned. It has to be earned.
Like everything in Hill House, that terror gets muted, slowed down and picked over so much that it ends up banal and lifeless.
The "Friends" soap opera ended predictably and blandly last night, with no big surprises, just two little ones -- Monica's and Chandler's twins.
Modernizing the original's much-beloved and extremely glamorous world has for some reason meant making it drearier, more awkward, and overall less joyful to inhabit.
"Marvel's Jessica Jones" gets off on the wrong foot in Season 3 and stays there until the lackluster end.
Mahershala Ali is the most notable thing about this third season that desperately tries to imitate the first season. [Full Review in Spanish]

Atill struggling with the same generic Marvel-on-Netflix issue: a master plot that just isn't dense enough to stretch over the episode order, leading to stop-and-start pacing, repetitive conversations and secondary characters that overstay their welcome.
Valhalla isn’t terrible. But it feels mostly like more of the same, without having much of an identity to itself. In a crowded landscape, that doesn’t give it a lot to fight for.
It might have worked effectively as a 3-hour movie, but at 7 hours doled out over eight episodes, Losing Alice dribs and drabs, but mostly drabs.
This is the most apocalyptic-y apocalypse ever, but it carries no real weight. Then when you find out what has to be done to save the universe, it just feels very underwhelming. Samurais, really?
If you enjoyed season 1 you'll be perfectly happy with this addition, but it doesn't do anything interesting with a character who should feel more relevant to our current political climate.
[What If...? is] bite-sized chunks of comic book fun, however [the show doesn't] go further than being half-hearted fan service.
It's nice that HBO has turned out another handsomely produced, manifestly serious mini-series for the wonderful actress Kate Winslet. It would be nicer if those series were worth her time and talent.
In its final season, the series seems to have exhausted its stores of surprises.
Aside from a subplot involving cultural reparations that doesn't entirely land, it would have been nice to see a bit more exposition about what point "The White Lotus" is ultimately trying to make.
Its strong start meanders to [a] repetitive, inevitable end.

Ever since the series’ first season, Killing Eve has been stuck in a weird holding pattern when it comes to these characters... And in the final season, don’t we -- and these characters -- deserve more?
Its strong start meanders to [a] repetitive, inevitable end.
It's meant as an episode of reflection, but because previous episodes have given the relationship a flimsy foundation, Scenes still ends on its flattest note.

The series, which evokes YA soaps like The OC and Gossip Girl, is pleasant enough, if blandly formulaic: full of breathless kisses, swim suits, dances, and mood-supporting pop songs - plus boozing, hooking up, and cheating, bathed in fumbling innocence.
Anyone returning, hoping for the old Rock rather than the new, is bound to be disappointed in this strained outing.
The depictions of real-life actors border on mimicry... The various Mafia personages appear to have watched The Godfather once too often.
Defending Jacob suffers greatly from its format, stretching 120 minutes of story max into eight hours of episodic television.

No matter how much you can appreciate the character's journey, it's not easy for any actor to carry this type of story, but Harper would make you believe otherwise. Here's hoping he gets even better material moving forward.
For a story centered on the exploits of a frightened, isolated teenager, the show remains remarkably devoid of any sense of fear, excitement, or passion.
Disney Plus's new Marvel show WandaVision promises a surreal spin on a 1960s sitcom reality. But so far, it's delivered little more than winks and nods to Marvel Cinematic Universe loyalists.
The action, when it comes, is lively, if predictable, but The Wheel of Time buckles under chunks of tedious exposition.
Defending Jacob feels like a huge miss for Apple TV+.
There are worse fantasy series and films out there, to be sure, but none of them were dumb enough to give their monsters a name that rhymes with "bollocks".
Anyone returning, hoping for the old Rock rather than the new, is bound to be disappointed in this strained outing.
It's often snobby and more than occasionally mean. It has a thin, subtle story, and lacks memorable set pieces.

"Peacemaker" exposes a bigger problem: in a minor role with an ensemble of zany characters, Cena's witty banter felt like a breath of fresh air. In a eight-hour episodic series with lackluster supporting players, Cena struggles to carry the load.
You can violate the laws of the universe you created, using a raft of new characters in whom we have no investment, or you can drag nine episodes' worth of doing so over 22 hours of TV. Not both.
Anatomy of a Scandal struggles to thread the needle between [its] two impulses, resulting in a show that’s unsatisfying as either a lurid thriller or a serious drama.

Those who've been just as mystified, expecting a third season to answer the many questions it's raised, or at least a deeper dive following the supernatural events of the Season One cliffhanger, will be terribly disappointed.
For its final episode, The Twilight Zone gives us something it spent most of its time railing against: a happy ending of perfect, selfish bliss.
Never tries something original when a cliché will do instead.

"Looking For Alaska" is nostalgic for itself, like it's admiring itself in a mirror instead of making eye contact. This neutralizes the immediacy and intimacy that can make coming-of-age stories so special.
With so much time taken up with gabbing there was little left for the kind of spectacle that made the first series a hit.
After that first episode ends, and Mann hands off the show to other directors, an impression starts to build that the best "Vice'' has to offer is behind it.
The way Ike silkily asserts control over Marty's life, and why Marty was susceptible to it, is a key element to all of this. But the show's approach is weirdly miscalculated.
This is all pretty stiff, predictable stuff, built around the operatic pangs of teen romance.
Rhimes isn't shy about availing herself of artistic license. In this story, however, she forgoes fleshing out her characters and bloats each episode's runtime instead.
Watching the series attempt to make sense of itself, it’s tempting to believe that it began as three separate Michelle, Betty, and Eleanor shows before The First Lady slapped them together into one.
Sharp Objects scratches the surface of being interesting but can't overcome its dull edges.

It is a show that takes itself so seriously that, when former child actor Thomas Brodie-Sangster turns up dressed like an escapee from the Wild West, you don't know whether it's meant to be funny or not
My real problem with Scandal isn’t that it’s trashy or muddled in its message. I was mostly lost wondering who to care about... What’s really missing in this Anatomy lesson is its soul.

Show: Once Upon a Time in Wonderland
Review: It's all meant to be a paean to the imagination. Too bad the effects pry some of us out of our imaginations and into the tech lab.
The Thing About Pam offers an intriguing but tonally off-putting rehash of a familiar true crime story.
Watching the story unfold, as Rudd's psychiatrist manipulates Ferrell's patient utterly and completely over the course of decades,is sometimes like scraping your knuckles on a cheese grater.
This spy thriller hitches its wagon to an insufferable performance.
After watching Season 2, I struggle to be certain what this show is about. The answer, at this point, really isn't "a morning show."
Iron Fist's sophomore season isn't able to right the many wrongs from its first. Don't waste your time on this one.
I never understood the appeal of The Flight Attendant, and I still don't.
Despite able performers and potent themes, the show is so addicted to chaos that it squanders its chance to say anything substantive.
It's a deeply terrifying story of manipulation and abuse that plays like a comedy, sometimes when it doesn't mean to, but isn't all that funny when it's trying to be.
Live Another Day feels terribly dated.
Part reality competition and part train wreck, this is a formulaic series produced to make its cast look pathetic.
My real problem with Scandal isn’t that it’s trashy or muddled in its message. I was mostly lost wondering who to care about... What’s really missing in this Anatomy lesson is its soul.

There is much to recommend Sharp Objects: its visual language is rich and fugal (blades, pigs, fans recur) and rewards close watching. But the dissatisfaction of the show's conclusion speaks to a larger confusion in the aim of the series.

As rendered in this iteration of King's epic, that mix of realism and fantasy results in a disjointed, tonally inconsistent work that manages to both over-condense aspects of the original saga and overstay its welcome.
Seven hours of boredom that test the beatlemania of the most devoted beatlemaniac. [Full review in Spanish]
The final season of House of Cards is too weird and atonal to ignore completely, but it's not good enough to recommend.
Every possible sports cliché lands with a thud, the dialogue is clunky and the attempt to frame the story as a rebellion against racism falls flat.
Watch Mommy Dead and Dearest as well as the various interviews with Gypsy Rose Blanchard instead; they'll be a lot more fascinating to watch than The Act.
Maybe the show will improve when it kicks into the case-of-the-week format and ramps up the nonsensical effects of this mysterious pill, but I don't have high hopes.

It is a show that takes itself so seriously that, when former child actor Thomas Brodie-Sangster turns up dressed like an escapee from the Wild West, you don't know whether it's meant to be funny or not
But both the jokes and the character beats that fuel Invincible are too sporadic to make the series feel anything more than sputtering. Unassailable, it is not.
Okay, it's possible I'm overreacting here just a smidge. But Spike's version of The Mist is one dumb piece of work.

It's not heavy-handed and it doesn't dumb down its audience (although you do have to buy into the NZT brainpower stuff), it just feels like it's missing something, and I think that something may be a level of investment in the characters.

While the strong ensemble cast made for a promising set-up, the series was besmirched by an increasingly infuriating script and a trite ending that had this viewer hurling decaying vegetables at the screen.
This spy thriller hitches its wagon to an insufferable performance.
It's not dark enough or funny enough, or meaningful enough or irreverent enough.
For those who enjoyed the original inclined to ask, "Why do I need this?," the answer is pretty well "You don't," other than a promised new coda to the story written by King.
